citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
On 18MAR2025 an older lioness, and older lion, and a black African leopard were observed with decreased muscle mass
with hips, ribs, and spine prominently displayed under the skin. These animals have not been evaluated or treated by the
attending veterinarian to diagnose any dietary insufficiency, diseases, or injuries accounting for the loss of body condition.
At the time of this inspection the Attending Veterinarian (AV) advised he had not been consulted or requested by the
facility to examine or treat these animals since the last routine inspection on 03DEC2024. Each dealer or exhibitor shall
establish and maintain programs of adequate veterinary care that include the use of appropriate methods to prevent,
control, diagnose, and treat diseases and injuries.

As of the date of the inspection, there are multiple instances of inaccurate or missing records of animals on hand,
including acquisitions and dispositions (purchases/births and sales/deaths).
• Disposition records for sales, donations, exchanges or deaths are missing. This includes but is not limited to three ducks
and one llama which were included on previous inspections but currently no documentation is available and the animals
are not present.
• Animals on hand contains an inaccurate inventory count, including but not limited to a llama and three ducks that were
still on inventory but no longer at the facility.
These records are necessary to assess the health and wellbeing of the animals on site and allow tracking of animals
being used for regulatory purposes. Ensure the inventory of all animals on hand is up to date and acquisitions and
dispositions are accurately recorded including animals born on site and any deaths.

There is no readily identifiable facility attendant present throughout the zoo in areas where between 50 and 100 combined
sheep, goats, llama, and deer roam free and have contact with and are hand fed by the public. A responsible,
knowledgeable, and readily identifiable employee or attendant must always be present during periods of public contact.
Correct by having responsible, knowledgeable, and readily identifiable employees or attendants present at all times during
periods of public contact.

Multiple enclosures need repair:
• Fixed metal pipes with jagged edges remain exposed in the middle of the elk outdoor enclosures which could cause
injury to the animals.
• The fencing surrounding the outdoor enclosure for an adult male lion, “Pharoh” has the support poles on the
inside of the chain link fencing and not on the outside. The fencing was again observed to be bowing outward from the
frame of the enclosure in one corner and appeared to no longer remain in good repair. This could potentially lead to
detachment of the chain-link fence from the support poles, and currently there is a potential for injuries to extremities such
as paws getting caught between the fence and the pole.
• Sharp points from wire fencing and wood are observed in the enclosures for camel, hoof stock, wallaby, and yak and
could cause injuries to the animals contained therein.
The indoor and outdoor housing facilities shall be structurally sound and shall be maintained in good repair to protect the
animals from injury and to contain the animals.

There is a massive amount of metal, piles of rotting hay, cardboard boxes, tractor parts, overflowing trash cans, and other
scattered debris in the area surrounding the hay storage barn and adjacent to the hoof stock holding enclosure.
Accumulated food waste, bedding, trash, and debris compromises animal welfare and will attract vermin, odor and
disease hazards. Disposal facilities shall be provided and operated to remove all waste in a timely manner to reduce
odors and disease hazards and minimize fly and vermin infestation.

A 10-inch-wide fencing plank is missing from the perimeter fence, clearly visible and accessible from the public parking
lot. An incomplete perimeter fence could allow unauthorized people and animals to access the zoo animals and cause
harm. Also, if an animal escaped its primary enclosure, it could leave the zoo and be injured or pose danger to the
general public. The facility must be enclosed by a perimeter fence that is sufficient to keep animals and unauthorized
persons out so that it protects the animals as well as function as a secondary containment system for the animals in the
facility.

During inspection two lions (Isabella and Javri) and one black leopard (Onyx) were underweight with hip bones, ribs and
spine prominent while one spotted leopard was overweight. The facility representative said these animals are fed 20 to 40
pounds for lions and around 10 to 20 pounds for leopards consisting of semi-frozen raw chicken or red meat daily. The
amount and type of meat per individual animal is not weighed and therefore these animals’ diets do not account for age,
metabolism, disease state, or climatic conditions, especially for the two lions, black leopard and spotted leopard.
Furthermore, the label for the dietary supplement with calcium is not being followed. The supplement, in granular form, is
sprinkled on the raw meat and the facility assumes the individual animals will ingest an adequate amount as labeled, but
there is no way of confirming the animals are receiving adequate supplementation (such as a dedicated individual
meatball). Food must be of sufficient quantity and nutritive value to maintain all animals in good health and prepared with
consideration for the age, species, condition, size, and type of the animal. Correct by feeding the correct amount required
for each animal and supplement by making sure each individual is ingesting the correct dose as instructed by someone
with adequate dietary training in the species.
The leafy green diet offered to the Patagonian cavies was presented to them on the ground which was sullied with feces
and soil. Food must be wholesome, palatable, and free from contamination. Correct by feeding cavy diet in a sanitary food
receptacle which can be accessible to the animals and readily cleaned and sanitized.
Food shall be wholesome palatable and free from contamination and of sufficient quantity and nutritive value to maintain
all animals in good health, taking into consideration individual requirements.

The facility does not have an adequate program of pest control with regards to rodents. At inspection, live rats were seen
on structures within the storage shed including on furniture, the floor, rafters and framing of walls and ceiling. Rodents and
other pests harm animal welfare by harboring diseases and parasites that can be transmitted to vulnerable zoo animals. A
safe and effective program for the control of insects, ectoparasites, and avian and mammalian pests must be established
and maintained.

The pond enclosure housing ducks, geese and swans contains resting surfaces with upturned wire mesh with sharp
points. These hazards could cause injury to the animals contained therein. Indoor and outdoor housing facilities shall be
structurally sound and shall be maintained in good repair to protect the animals from injury and to contain the animals.
Correct by removing sharp points from the enclosure and maintaining all surfaces in good repair.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
Additional Inspectors:
Eduardo Vivas, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

narrative:
2.40(b)(3)  Direct Repeat
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
On 18MAR2025 an older lioness, and older lion, and a black African leopard were observed with decreased muscle mass 
with hips, ribs, and spine prominently displayed under the skin. These animals have not been evaluated or treated by the 
attending veterinarian to diagnose any dietary insufficiency, diseases, or injuries accounting for the loss of body condition. 
At the time of this inspection the Attending Veterinarian (AV) advised he had not been consulted or requested by the 
facility to examine or treat these animals since the last routine inspection on 03DEC2024. Each dealer or exhibitor shall 
establish and maintain programs of adequate veterinary care that include the use of appropriate methods to prevent, 
control, diagnose, and treat diseases and injuries. 
2.75(b)(1)  Repeat
   
Records: Dealers and exhibitors. 
As of the date of the inspection, there are multiple instances of inaccurate or missing records of animals on hand, 
including acquisitions and dispositions (purchases/births and sales/deaths). 
• Disposition records for sales, donations, exchanges or deaths are missing. This includes but is not limited to three ducks

These records are necessary to assess the health and wellbeing of the animals on site and allow tracking of animals 
being used for regulatory purposes. Ensure the inventory of all animals on hand is up to date and acquisitions and 
dispositions are accurately recorded including animals born on site and any deaths. 
2.131(d)(2)  Repeat
   
Handling of animals. 
There is no readily identifiable facility attendant present throughout the zoo in areas where between 50 and 100 combined 
sheep, goats, llama, and deer roam free and have contact with and are hand fed by the public. A responsible, 
knowledgeable, and readily identifiable employee or attendant must always be present during periods of public contact.

periods of public contact.

3.125(a)  Repeat
   
Facilities, general. 
Multiple enclosures need repair:  
• Fixed metal pipes with jagged edges remain exposed in the middle of the elk outdoor enclosures which could cause 
injury to the animals. 
•  The fencing surrounding the outdoor enclosure for an adult male lion, “Pharoh” has the support poles on the

could cause injuries to the animals contained therein. 
The indoor and outdoor housing facilities shall be structurally sound and shall be maintained in good repair to protect the 
animals from injury and to contain the animals. 
3.125(d) 
   
Facilities, general. 
There is a massive amount of metal, piles of rotting hay, cardboard boxes, tractor parts, overflowing trash cans, and other 
scattered debris in the area surrounding the hay storage barn and adjacent to the hoof stock holding enclosure. 
Accumulated food waste, bedding, trash, and debris compromises animal welfare and will attract vermin, odor and 
disease hazards. Disposal facilities shall be provided and operated to remove all waste in a timely manner to reduce 
odors and disease hazards and minimize fly and vermin infestation. 
3.127(d)  Repeat
   
Facilities, outdoor. 
A 10-inch-wide fencing plank is missing from the perimeter fence, clearly visible and accessible from the public parking 
lot. An incomplete perimeter fence could allow unauthorized people and animals to access the zoo animals and cause 
harm. Also, if an animal escaped its primary enclosure, it could leave the zoo and be injured or pose danger to the 
general public. The facility must be enclosed by a perimeter fence that is sufficient to keep animals and unauthorized 
persons out so that it protects the animals as well as function as a secondary containment system for the animals in the 
facility. 
3.129(a) 
   
Feeding. 
During inspection two lions (Isabella and Javri) and one black leopard (Onyx) were underweight with hip bones, ribs and 
spine prominent while one spotted leopard was overweight. The facility representative said these animals are fed 20 to 40 
pounds for lions and around 10 to 20 pounds for leopards consisting of semi-frozen raw chicken or red meat daily. The

Furthermore, the label for the dietary supplement with calcium is not being followed. The supplement, in granular form, is

sprinkled on the raw meat and the facility assumes the individual animals will ingest an adequate amount as labeled, but 
there is no way of confirming the animals are receiving adequate supplementation (such as a dedicated individual

The leafy green diet offered to the Patagonian cavies was presented to them on the ground which was sullied with feces 
and soil. Food must be wholesome, palatable, and free from contamination. Correct by feeding cavy diet in a sanitary food 
receptacle which can be accessible to the animals and readily cleaned and sanitized. 
Food shall be wholesome palatable and free from contamination and of sufficient quantity and nutritive value to maintain 
all animals in good health, taking into consideration individual requirements. 
3.131(d)  Repeat
   
Sanitation. 
The facility does not have an adequate program of pest control with regards to rodents. At inspection, live rats were seen 
on structures within the storage shed including on furniture, the floor, rafters and framing of walls and ceiling. Rodents and 
other pests harm animal welfare by harboring diseases and parasites that can be transmitted to vulnerable zoo animals. A 
safe and effective program for the control of insects, ectoparasites, and avian and mammalian pests must be established

3.150(a)  Repeat
   
Facilities, general. 
The pond enclosure housing ducks, geese and swans contains resting surfaces with upturned wire mesh with sharp 
points. These hazards could cause injury to the animals contained therein. Indoor and outdoor housing facilities shall be 
structurally sound and shall be maintained in good repair to protect the animals from injury and to contain the animals. 
Correct by removing sharp points from the enclosure and maintaining all surfaces in good repair. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
Eduardo Vivas, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

species.common: RED FOX (INCLUDES SILVER FOX & CROSS FOX)
DOMESTIC DUCK INCLUDING ALL DOMESTIC BREEDS
